prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for switching my birth control without telling my mom
So I’m 17 and yesterday it was time for me to go get depo shot (every three months). I have been looking at the nexplanon implant (every 5 years) because I thought it would be more convenient and overall better. 

I brought up the implant with my mom and she told me to wait until I’m 18 (3 months from now) and she wouldn’t even talk to me as to why I wanted it. That was it. 

I went and during the appointment I asked if I could do the implant and they said they could do it for me and I went ahead and got it inserted (mom wasn’t there). When I told my mom she hung up the phone on me. She forgot about it and things were fine and when it was mentioned today she said she forgot about that and she was upset that I went and got it. I told her that it would be better for me to go ahead and get it now while I’m not working full time like I plan to be after I turn 18 in the summer and my arm can heal fine (I work retail and have to lift heavy cases and stuff).

She said she wanted to do ‘research on it’ and kept asking if I even knew the side effects which are no different that the depo shot.

I feel like she’s overreacting and mind you she has an IUD so I’m not too sure why she’s going so hard about it. What would’ve been the difference between now and 18? I’m not sure why she thinks I’m not allowed to make choices like these on my own. 

Also I’m not sexually active or anything and she knows that. I just wanted something more long term. 

AITA?
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. The situation is about a 17-year-old who decided to get the Nexplanon implant without telling their mom. The mom had previously said to wait until they turn 18, but the author went ahead anyway.

First, I need to consider the legal aspects. In many places, minors can consent to certain medical treatments, especially reproductive health. So maybe the author had the legal right to make this decision. But laws vary by location, so I should check if that's a factor here. The story doesn't specify the location, so I might have to assume a general case where minors can consent to birth control.

Then there's the ethical side. The mom did express her opinion and asked the author to wait. The author felt it was a better choice for their circumstances, like not working full-time yet, which makes the healing process easier. The mom is upset because she feels the author didn't inform her and is now doing research on the implant. The author points out that the mom uses an IUD herself, so maybe the mom's reaction is inconsistent.

But the mom is the parent, so she might feel responsible for making sure the author makes informed decisions. The author argues they're not sexually active, so maybe the mom thinks it's unnecessary. However, the author is planning for the future. The mom's overreaction might stem from wanting to protect her child, even if her reasoning is unclear.

Is the author wrong for not informing the mom? It depends on the parent-child relationship. In some families, open communication is expected, so not telling the mom could be seen as disrespectful. But if the author felt the mom was dismissive and wouldn't listen, maybe acting independently was necessary. The author did mention the reasons, like healing time before starting full-time work.

The mom hanging up and then being upset might indicate she's hurt that the author didn't respect her initial request. But the author had valid reasons. The question is whether the author had the right to make this decision without the mom's consent. Legally, if allowed, then no. Ethically, it's a gray area. The author might not be in the wrong, but the situation shows a communication breakdown. The answer might hinge on the legal ability to consent and the context of the parent's role. If the author could legally make the decision, then B (not in the wrong) makes sense. If not, then A. But since the author did get the implant and the mom is upset, the answer might be B, considering the author's autonomy and valid reasons.
